IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 13620 S0926-860X(12)00188-3 10.1016/j.apcata.2012.03.045 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Platinum catalysts’ XRD patterns. Fig. 2 Catalysts’ Pt 4f XPS spectra. Fig. 3 Differential IR spectra of carbon monoxide adsorbed on (A) Pt(1.0)/SiO2, (B) Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2, and (C) Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 pretreated in air or hydrogen at 400°C, followed by exposure to carbon monoxide mixed gas (1000ppmv/He balance, Hankook special gas) at 50°C. Fig. 4 Platinum catalysts’ XRD patterns after hydrothermal treatment at 850°C for 48h. Fig. 5 Platinum catalysts’ XRD patterns after sulfur poisoning at 400°C for 2h. Fig. 6 Platinum catalysts’ S 2p XPS spectra after sulfur poisoning at 400°C for 2h. Fig. 7 NO conversions and yields of N-materials with respect to the temperature of the H2-SCR reaction without oxygen over Pt(1.0)/SiO2 and Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 catalysts. Feed gas: NO 480ppmv/H2 0.8%/He balance. Fig. 8 NO conversions and yields of N-materials with respect to the temperature of the H2-SCR reaction with oxygen over Pt(1.0)/SiO2, Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 and Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 catalysts. Feed gas: NO 480ppmv/O2 5%/H2 0.8%/He balance. Incorporation of zirconia onto silica for improved Pt/SiO2 catalysts for the selective reduction of NO by H2 Se Min Park a Hoi-Gu Jang a Eun Seok Kim b Hyun-Sik Han b Gon Seo a ⁎ a School of Applied Chemical Engineering and the Research Institute for Catalysis, Chonnam National University, Gwangju 500-757, Republic of Korea b Heesung Catalyst Corp., 1251-6 Jungwang-Dong, Shihung, Gyeonggi, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 62 530 1876; fax: +82 62 530 1819. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Zirconia incorporated on silica improves the stability of platinum dispersed on it. ► Ammonia is produced over Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 under excess oxygen. ► Pt/Zr–SiO2 exhibits good catalysis in the H2-SCR of NO at 75–150°C. ► Zirconia incorporation improves platinum catalysts in the H2-SCR of NO. The incorporation of zirconia onto the silica supports of platinum catalysts improved the selective reduction of NO by hydrogen in comparison to platinum catalysts supported on silica and alumina. The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and the adsorption of carbon monoxide. Their performances were examined in a flow microreactor and by in situ IR spectroscopy. The incorporation of zirconia onto silica created many strong acid sites and stabilized the dispersed platinum. It aided the adsorption of NO and enhanced the formation of ammonia on the platinum catalysts, even in the presence of excess oxygen. The formation of ammonia from NO and the subsequent removal of NO through reaction with ammonia considerably improved the conversion of NO and the yield of N2. The presence of zirconia also improved the stability of the supported platinum against hydrothermal treatment. Keywords Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) NO Hydrogen Platinum Silica Zirconia incorporation 1 Introduction Diesel engines are highly fuel-efficient and therefore widely used, though their emissions of particulates and oxides of nitrogen (NOx) contribute to problems such as air pollution [1]. Diesel oxidation catalysts can remove unburned hydrocarbons, particulates, and soot through combustion with excess air in the engines’ exhausts. However, the reductive removal of NOx to nitrogen under such an oxidative atmosphere is difficult. Improvements of engines’ structures and operating conditions can considerably reduce NOx emissions, though increasingly stringent regulation requires further reductions of NOx emissions [1,2]. The injection of urea into the exhausts of diesel engines before selective catalytic reduction (SCR) beds allows conversion of the oxidative atmosphere of the exhaust to a reductive one, allowing the selective reduction of NOx to N2 [1,3–5]. The installation of urea storage and injection apparatus and the cost of urea solution reduce the economic feasibility of such SCR systems. However, such systems have been installed in trucks and buses to satisfy emission regulations, because the fuel efficiency is very important on these vehicles. The necessary infrastructure for the supply of urea solution and the prevention of ammonia slip, a secondary contamination due the great variance of vehicles’ running conditions, retard these systems’ wide application. The SCR of NOx by hydrogen (H2-SCR) has been studied over various platinum-impregnated oxide catalysts, since hydrogen is an excellent reductant [6–13]. The use of hydrogen produced in the reforming of unburned hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide in the exhaust of diesel engines has many advantages: no supply infrastructure is required and secondary contamination is prevented. Although NOx can be selectively reduced to N2 over noble metal catalysts in the absence of oxygen, the excess oxygen in diesel engines’ exhaust severely lowers the selectivity of the H2-SCR due to a preference for H2 combustion by oxygen that consumes much of the hydrogen. The replacement of alumina by mixed oxides such as TiO2–ZrO2 or MgO–CeO2 enhances the selectivity for N2 in the H2-SCR of NOx [6,7]. Pt(1wt%)/TiO2–ZrO2 has shown high conversions of NO and high selectivities for N2, even in an environment of excess of 10vol% oxygen at below 100°C. The adsorption of NO on transition metal oxides as nitrate species facilitates its reduction by hydrogen atoms activated on the platinum, resulting in highly selective catalysis. Pt/MgO–CeO2 prepared by impregnating platinum on a mixed oxide of magnesia and ceria exhibited a very high conversion of NO and high selectivity for H2-SCR at 180°C. The hindrance of H2-SCR by excess oxygen does not cripple the system because NO species are activated at the interface of magnesia and ceria. However, both these catalysts have very narrow temperature ranges for high performance: the former performs poorly above 100°C and the latter only performs well at around 180°C. The dispersion and loading of platinum also sensitively influence their activities and selectivities. Pt–MnOx works effectively in the H2-SCR of NO: NO produces ammonia by reacting with hydrogen, which then subsequently reduces NO through NH3-SCR [8]. The consecutive removal of NO through the formation of ammonia and the reduction of NO by this ammonia results in the high performance of the H2-SCR. The formation of ammonia on the MnOx from the reaction of NOx with hydrogen atoms activated on the platinum suppresses reactions between hydrogen and oxygen. The ammonia stored on the MnOx effectively reduces NOx through NH3-SCR and guarantees a steady, high performance without being sensitive to changes of the composition of the exhaust. The formation of ammonia and its subsequent reaction with NO have also been observed on a physical mixture of Pt/ZrO2 and H-ZSM-5 [10]: the reaction of NO with hydrogen over Pt/ZrO2 produced ammonia and H-ZSM-5 reduced NO through reaction with ammonia, resulting in the high removal of NO. Alumina is a widely used support for noble metals catalysts due to its moderate interactions with the metals allowing high dispersions and hydrothermal stability [9]. However, the formation of aluminum sulfate through the reaction of the aluminum of the alumina and the exhaust's sulfur compounds can cause severe deactivation [14]. The eventual conversion of platinum to platinum–aluminum alloy during use at high temperatures also necessitates alternative supports to alumina [15]. Zirconia is a good catalytic support for the H2-SCR of NO; it has a considerable inherent catalytic activity for the SCR of NO and a high stability due to its high melting point. Acid sites formed at the interfaces of the mixed oxides can store ammonia produced from the reaction of NOx with hydrogen and supply it to the SCR of NOx [16]. Although conventional zirconia has a small surface area and its hardness make it difficult to shape, the incorporation of zirconia onto silica supports with high surface areas easily overcomes these limitations. Platinum catalysts supported on such zirconia-incorporated silica have shown high activity and stability in the combustion of propane even after aging at 800°C for 50h [16]. The incorporation of zirconia onto silica can significantly improve the dispersion and stability of subsequently dispersed noble metals. Combining silica with zirconia combines the inertness of silica, the strong interactions of zirconia with platinum and NOx, and the formation of strong acid sites at the interfaces of the silica and zirconia, leading to a promising catalyst for the H2-SCR of NOx. This work reports the preparation of platinum catalysts supported on zirconia-incorporated silica and their catalytic activities and selectivities in the H2-SCR of NO. The formation of ammonia and reduction of NO by hydrogen and ammonia over the catalysts was investigated by in situ IR spectroscopy. The catalysts’ performance after exposure to sulfur compounds and hydrothermal treatment is discussed in terms of platinum dispersion and activity and in comparison with platinum catalysts supported on conventional silica and alumina. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Zirconia was incorporated onto amorphous silica (Si635, Aldrich) using a zirconium propoxide (99.99% Aldrich) precursor. Silica was suspended in an alcoholic solution of zirconium propoxide and reacted with zirconium species at 80°C for 4h under reflux. After sufficient washing to remove non-reacted alkoxide, the filtrates were dried in an oven at 100°C and calcined at 450°C for 4h. An alumina (Sasol) was used a support for the preparation of a reference catalyst. Platinum was impregnated on the zirconia-incorporated silica by a conventional method. Platinum was loaded at 0.1, 1.0, and 4.0wt% by adjusting the concentration of tetraamineplatinum nitrate (99%, Aldrich) solution. The platinum-impregnated catalysts were reduced at 400°C in a 100ml/min flow of H2/N2 (50/50vol%, Hankook Special Gas) for 2h. The platinum catalysts were denoted by their wt% loadings in parentheses after Pt, e.g. Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 represents a catalyst with 1wt% Pt loading. 2.2 Characterization of the platinum catalysts The catalysts’ chemical compositions were determined by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, PerkinElmer Optima 4300 DV). Diffraction patterns were recorded on a high-resolution X-ray diffractometer (HR-XRD, Rigaku, Ultima III) using Cu Kα radiation filtered by a nickel filter. Adsorption isotherms of nitrogen at the liquid nitrogen temperature were obtained using automatic adsorption measuring apparatus (Mirae SI nanoPorosity-XG). 0.1g samples were evacuated at 250°C for 2h prior to exposure to the nitrogen gas. The surface areas of the platinum catalysts were calculated by applying the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation to the obtained isotherms. The dispersion of platinum was observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM 2000 FXII, JEOL). Catalysts dispersed in acetone were sonicated and sampled using a carbon grid. The surface elements’ compositions and chemical states were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS, VG MultiLab 2000) using a monochromated Mg Kα X-ray source (300W). Their binding energies were calibrated using the C1s (285eV) peak as a reference. The surface composition of zirconium and platinum were calculated from their corresponding peaks. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) profiles of ammonia from the platinum catalysts were recorded using laboratory-made apparatus. 0.1g samples were charged in quartz tubes of 6mm O.D. and activated in a 100ml/min flow of helium gas (Shinil Gas, 99.995%) at 500°C for 1h. They were then saturated in a 100ml/min flow of ammonia mixed gas (1000ppmv/He balance, Hankook Special Gas) and purged with the helium flow at 150°C. The samples were heated to 600°C at 10°C/min and the desorbed ammonia was detected by mass spectrometer (Balzers, QMS200). 2.3 H2-SCR of NO over the platinum catalysts The H2-SCR of NO over the platinum catalysts was carried out in an atmospheric flow reactor. 0.1g each catalyst was charged in a quartz tube of 6mm O.D. and activated in a 100ml/min helium gas flow at 500°C for 1h. After cooling to 50°C, adsorption equilibrium was established using a 100ml/min flow of a NO/O2 gas mixture (NO 480ppmv/O2 5vol%/He balance, Hankook Special Gas). The H2/N2 gas mixture was then continuously injected into the NO/O2 gas mixture to maintain a 0.8% concentration of hydrogen. The reduction of NO and the consumed hydrogen were measured using a combined detection system comprising a mass spectrometer (Balzers, QMS200) and a non-dispersive infrared (NDIR) gas analyzer (Siemens, ULTRAMAT 6). The concentrations of NO (m/e =30), NO2 (m/e =46), N2O (m/e =44), N2 (m/e =28), H2O (m/e =18 and 17) and NH3 (m/e =15, 16, and 17) in the product stream were measured from their mass signals. The fragmentation patterns of these products at the lowest ionization potential obtained from their standard gases were used in the concentration calculations. The concentrations of NO and N2O were simultaneously confirmed by the NDIR gas analyzer and that of NO2 by a NOx analyzer (ECO Physic, CLD 844 CMH). The conversion of NO (X NO) was defined as the fraction of NO converted to N-containing species such as N2, N2O, NH3, and NO2, the yield of each was calculated from the NO consumed for their production with respect to the NO fed. 2.4 IR study of the platinum catalysts An FT-IR spectrophotometer (BIO-RAD, FTS-175C) with an in situ cell (Graseby Specac) was used to investigate the materials adsorbed and occluded on the platinum catalysts during the H2-SCR of NO. A 10mg catalyst wafer in the in situ IR cell was activated under a 100ml/min helium gas flow at 500°C for 1h. After cooling to 50°C, carbon monoxide gas (CO 1000ppmv/He balance, Hankook Special Gas) at 100ml/min was fed into the reactor for 30min. IR spectra of the carbon monoxide adsorbed on the catalysts were recorded by accumulating 16 scans at 4000–700cm−1 with a resolution of 4cm−1 to lower the signal-to-noise ratio. The adsorption of NO and its reduction by hydrogen on the platinum catalysts were also monitored by FT-IR spectrophotometry. A 10mg catalyst wafer was pretreated with 100ml/min helium gas at 400°C for 1h. After cooling to 50°C, a NO/O2/H2 gas mixture (NO 480ppmv/O2 5%/H2 0.8%/He balance, Hankook Special Gas) was supplied at 100ml/min. The temperature was maintained for 30min and then raised to 400°C at 10°C/min. The IR spectra of materials adsorbed and occluded on the catalysts were obtained as above. 2.5 Deactivation of the platinum catalysts by hydrothermal treatment and sulfur dioxide poisoning The platinum catalysts were held in a tubular furnace at 850°C under nitrogen (Shinil Gas, 99.995%) containing 10vol% water vapor for 48h. The content of water vapor was adjusted by controlling the temperature of a water vaporizer in a constant water bath. Sulfur dioxide poisoning was tested by exposing the platinum catalysts to a mixed flow of 20ml/min diluted sulfur dioxide gas (97%, Donga) and 80ml/min nitrogen containing 10vol% water vapor at 400°C for 2h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physico-chemical states of platinum catalysts The catalysts’ bulk and surface compositions (Table 1 ) show that zirconia was consistently incorporation onto silica at ca. 10wt%, and that platinum impregnation varied as 0.1, 1.0, and 4.0wt%. Since the atomic weights of zirconium and platinum are larger than those of silicon and oxygen, the contents of the formers in atomic percent are lower than those expressed in weight percent. Platinum was less present at the catalysts’ surfaces than in their bulks. Zirconia also showed lower surface concentrations than in the bulk. Contamination by carbon and oxygen on the surfaces reduced these surface contents. The presence of zirconia and platinum slightly lowered the catalysts’ surface areas, but the small decreases suggested that zirconia and platinum were highly dispersed on the silica. The small surface area of Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 reflected that of alumina itself. Sintering the platinum and zirconia induced their characteristic XRD diffraction peaks (Fig. 1 ). The high platinum loadings of Pt(4.0)/SiO2 and Pt(4.0)/Zr–SiO2 induced XRD peaks at 2θ =39.9°, 46.2°, and 67.4°, attributed to platinum metal. The moderate platinum loading of Pt(1.0)/SiO2 did not induce these peaks [PDF#04-0802]. Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 and Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 exhibited small, weak XRD peaks attributable to metallic platinum. Severe agglomeration of platinum metal did not occur on the catalysts with platinum at below 1.0 wt%; platinum impregnated at 4.0wt% sintered on the catalysts. The catalysts’ Pt 4f XPS spectra (Fig. 2 ) showed sufficiently intense peaks for quantitative analysis of chemical states only at the highest platinum loading of 4.0wt%. Pt(4.0)/Zr–SiO2 showed more intense peaks than Pt(4.0)/SiO2, indicating better platinum dispersion. The Pt 4f7/2 peaks’ binding energies were in the range of 70.8–71.5eV, confirming the platinum's metallic state [17]. The slightly higher binding energies shown by Pt(4.0)/Zr–SiO2 than by Pt(4.0)/SiO2 indicate the stronger interactions between platinum and zirconia. The adsorption state of carbon monoxide on the catalysts was shown by IR spectroscopy to vary with their supports (Fig. 3 ). The adsorption of carbon monoxide on Pt(1.0)/SiO2 and Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 caused the appearance of an absorption band at 2060–2070cm−1, attributed to its adsorption on the platinum metal [18]. Pretreatment with air reduced this band shown by Pt(1.0)/SiO2 but had little effect on that of Pt(1.0)/Al2O3. The IR spectra of carbon monoxide adsorbed on Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 varied according to the gas employed in the pretreatment. In the reduced state, a slightly larger absorption band of carbon monoxide was observed at 2069cm−1, indicating a better dispersion of platinum metal. A small band of carbon monoxide adsorbed on platinum oxide was observed at 2100cm−1 after its pretreatment in air [18]. The incorporation of zirconia onto the silica generated partially oxidized platinum in the oxidative atmosphere [16]. TEM showed that the dispersion of platinum in the 1.0wt% loaded samples varied with the support (Fig. S1). Platinum particles were agglomerated on silica, and were very fine and separated on the zirconia-incorporated silica. Alumina hosted large platinum particles. The incorporation of zirconia onto silica enhanced the dispersion of platinum, resulting in well dispersed highly uniform particles of around 5nm diameter. Although Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 used in this study was prepared without treating by hydrogen peroxide, not like in our previous paper [16], the calculation at elevated temperatures and for longer times led to high dispersion of platinum. The variation of the catalysts’ acidic properties with their supports was observed via the TPD of ammonia from the catalysts with 1.0wt% platinum loading (Fig. S2). Pt(1.0)/SiO2 did not show any peaks representing the desorption of ammonia, indicating a lack of acid sites. Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 exhibited a large ammonia desorption peak with a maximum at 270°C. The impregnation of zirconia onto silica created strong acid sites at the interfaces between them due to the difference in their electronegativities [16]. Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 also showed a wide, small desorption peak due to the acidity of alumina itself [14]. The hydrothermal treatment of platinum catalysts usually sinters the platinum, deactivating the catalysts [16]. XRD patterns of the 1.0wt% platinum catalysts before and after hydrothermal treatment at 850°C for 48h (Fig. 4 ) demonstrate the improved hydrothermal stability of the catalyst with zirconia-incorporated silica than those with silica or alumina. Pt(1.0)/SiO2 did not show any diffraction peaks attributed to platinum metal before the hydrothermal treatment; definite diffraction peaks of platinum metal were observed after the treatment 2θ =39.9° and 46.2°. Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 showed small diffraction peaks attributed to platinum metal before the hydrothermal treatment, which showed extremely small increases upon the treatment, indicating the catalyst's high stability. Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 also showed a notable increase in the diffraction peak at 2θ =39.0° attributed to platinum metal after the hydrothermal treatment. The incorporation of zirconia onto silica improved the resistance of the platinum to the hydrothermal treatment. Exposing platinum catalysts to wet sulfur dioxide at elevated temperatures causes the formation of sulfates. XRD patterns were recorded of the catalysts exposed to wet sulfur dioxide at 400°C for 2h (Fig. 5 ). No appreciable change was observed on Pt(1.0)/SiO2, indicating the high inertness of silica to the sulfur compounds. Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 produced zirconium sulfates in the presence of wet sulfur dioxide, Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 produced aluminum sulfate–though weak diffraction peaks were observed in both cases [PDF#24-1498, PDF#30-0043]. The particles of zirconium sulfate and aluminum sulfate were too small to compare using Sherrer's equation and their major diffraction peaks. The XPS spectra of the catalysts exposed to sulfur dioxide (Fig. 6 ) clearly show varying surface compositions according to the supports. No appreciable peaks attributed to sulfur was observed on Pt(1.0)/SiO2 or Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2. A definite S 2p XPS peak at 169.0eV was shown by Pt(1.0)/Al2O3, demonstrating the accumulation of aluminum sulfate on its external surface [19]. The surface composition of sulfur on Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 reached 15atom% after exposure to sulfur dioxide, representing a preferable spreading of aluminum sulfate on the surface. Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 behaved differently, showing a negligible XPS S 2p peak after exposure to sulfur dioxide. XRD showed the formation of zirconia sulfate, though the negligible XPS S peak suggests that it agglomerated into large particles or was present below the catalyst's surface. The incorporation of zirconia onto silica affected the catalysts’ platinum dispersion and acidity. XPS, TEM, and IR spectroscopy of carbon monoxide adsorption showed an appreciable improvement of platinum dispersion on the zirconia-incorporated silica. The strong metal support interaction between zirconia and platinum that would suppress the adsorption of carbon monoxide on platinum was not observed on Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2; the presence of partially oxidized platinum under an oxidative atmosphere reflected interactions between platinum and zirconia. The zirconia generated strong acid sites at its interfaces with silica, and thus Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 had more acid sites than Pt(1.0)/Al2O3. The incorporation of zirconia onto silica supports for platinum enhanced its resistance to hydrothermal treatment. Although zirconium sulfate was produced on Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 during exposure to wet sulfur dioxide, the external surface occupation of sulfur was negligible. In summary, platinum catalysts supported on the zirconia-incorporated silica were better dispersed and showed high acidity and improved resistances to hydrothermal and sulfur dioxide treatments. 3.2 Catalytic performances of the Pt-loaded catalysts The presence of oxygen in the NO/H2 gas mixture significantly influenced the catalysts’ activities and selectivities for N2 in the H2-SCR of NO. Supports such as SiO2 and Zr–SiO2 without containing platinum did not show any activity, indicating platinum is an essential active phase. The conversion of NO and the yields of N2, N2O, and NH3 in the H2-SCR of NO without oxygen were similar over Pt(1.0)/SiO2 and Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 (Fig. 7 ), indicating a negligible effect of the zirconia incorporation. NO conversion was high at 50–300°C; the yield of N2 was about 50%. The yield of N2O decreased with increasing temperature, while that of NH3 behaved oppositely. At low temperature, half the NO was converted to N2O, while the formation of NH3 replaced that of N2O as the reaction temperature increased. The variation of product yields with temperature over the catalysts in the absence of oxygen reflects the importance of the dissociative adsorption of NO on the platinum metal [20]. The oxygen species produced by the dissociation of NO were easily removed by the hydrogen atoms activated on the platinum. N atoms dispersed on the platinum metal reacted with each other to produce nitrogen molecules or with NO to form N2O. The low extent of NO dissociation resulted in higher yields of N2O at low temperature. The high proportion of NO at low temperatures increased the yield of N2O; the high proportion of dissociative adsorption of NO at high temperatures reduced N2O yield and increased NH3 yield due to the reaction between dissociative adsorbed N and H atoms. The presence of excess oxygen significantly affected the H2-SCR of NO over the platinum catalysts (Fig. 8 ). Ammonia was not detected in the product stream by the mass spectrometer and N2O was still produced above 150°C. The conversion of NO over Pt(1.0)/SiO2 was maximized at 95% at 100°C. Conversions at other temperatures were much lower: ca. 20% both at 50 and 200°C. The yield profiles of N2 and N2O with respect to temperature were similar to that of NO conversion. The N2 yield was low, peaking at 40% that of N2O was slightly higher, 50%. NO2 was produced above 150°C but at lower yields than over the other platinum catalysts. The similar trends of conversion and N2 and N2O yields of on Pt(1.0)/SiO2 indicate the suppression of the dissociative adsorption of NO on the metallic platinum by the excess oxygen. The competition between NO and excess oxygen for adsorption lowered the surface concentrations of NO and N, resulting in lower conversions. Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 exhibited better catalytic performance in the H2-SCR of NO than Pt(1.0)/SiO2 in terms of conversion and N2 yield. It maintained a high conversion of NO, above 80%, at 50–300°C and achieved high yields of N2, above 70%, at 100–125°C. The suppression of N2O formation at this temperature range resulted in high yields of N2, implying that zirconia incorporated onto silica contributed to the activation of NO and enhanced the formation of N2, since N2O was mainly produced by the reaction between N and NO on the platinum metal. Activated NO molecules on the zirconia reacted with H atoms activated on the platinum to produce N2 and NH3. The positive effects of zirconia on the catalysis of the H2-SCR of NO are clear. Although conversions on Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 were similarly high to those on Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2, N2 yields were consistently lower over the tested temperature range. The high yields of N2O and NO2 at low and high temperatures, respectively, over Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 resulted in the lower N2 yields. High platinum loading on Pt/Zr–SiO2 increased NO conversion and lowered the yield of N2; yields of N2O and NO2 increased with increasing platinum loading (Fig. S3). The negligible conversion of NO on Pt(0.1)/Zr–SiO2 at 50°C indicated the importance of platinum in the dissociative adsorption of NO for its conversion. High concentrations of NO and N on Pt(4.0)/Zr–SiO2 maintained high conversions even at higher temperatures, but high yields of N2O and NO2 lowered the yield of N2. Despite there being only a slight decrease of N2 yield with increased platinum loading, the high platinum loading was not profitable for the H2-SCR of NO. The considerable enhancement of N2 yield due to the use of the zirconia-incorporated silica support was due to the participation of the incorporated zirconia in the adsorption of NO. The adsorbed states of NO on the catalysts were shown by IR spectroscopy to vary considerably between supports (Fig. 9 ); reactions were conducted at 50–250°C. Only a simple absorption band at 1610cm−1, attributed to nitrate adsorbed on the platinum, appeared on Pt(1.0)/SiO2 after exposure to NO/H2/O2 [20]. This band gradually reduced with increasing temperature, despite the reactant containing NO and H2. No absorption bands were observed above 100°C. The negative band around 1620cm−1 was due to water desorption. The severe changes in the background adsorption of silica invalidated the spectra below 1300cm−1. The exposure of Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 to NO/H2/O2 resulted in clearly distinct spectra from those on observed on Pt(1.0)/SiO2. Several absorption bands were observed due to the adsorption of NO, the H2-SCR of NO, and the reaction between hydrogen and oxygen. The band at 1627cm−1 was assigned to water adsorbed and those at 1610 and 1589cm−1 were attributed to bidentate nitrate respectively adsorbed on platinum and zirconia [20]. The band at 1435cm−1 was attributed to ammonia adsorbed on Brönsted acid sites [9,21]. These bands confirmed the formation of water and ammonia during the H2-SCR of NO. With increasing temperature, the band representing bidentate nitrate adsorbed on platinum decreased and that representing bidentate nitrate adsorbed on zirconia maintained its intensity up to 150°C. The band attributed to ammonia adsorbed on Brönsted acid sites increased with increasing temperature up to 120°C and decreased with further increases. These bands became negligible above 200°C, except a negative band due to water desorption. The exposure of Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 to NO/H2/O2 resulted in very different IR spectra from those obtained using Pt(1.0)/SiO2 and Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2. Bands appeared at 1627, 1400, 1344, and 1230cm−1 appeared. The bands at 1400 and 1344cm−1 appeared after a considerable induction time. The band at 1627cm−1 was attributed to water adsorbed on acid sites. Those at 1400 and 1344cm−1 were related to ionic nitrate adsorbed on alumina and the band at 1230cm−1 to ionic nitrite [22]. The bands attributed to nitrate and nitrite decreased with increasing temperature; increases of temperature above 150°C caused the appearance of bands at 1544 and 1300cm−1, attributed to bidentate nitrate adsorbed on alumina. The formation of ammonia was not confirmed from the spectra recorded on Pt(1.0)/Al2O3. The IR spectra of adsorbed materials on Pt(1.0)/SiO2 did not provide any information on the progress of the H2-SCR of NO on it. Even the band attributed to NO bidentate adsorbed on platinum vanished at 90°C. However, various absorption bands relative to water, NO, and ammonia appeared on Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 upon its exposure to NO/H2/O2. Zirconia participated in the adsorption of NO, was involved in the formation of NH3 through the reaction between NO and H atoms activated on platinum metal, and the strong acid sites generated at the silica–zirconia interfaces stored ammonia. Although the details of the H2-SCR of NO on this catalyst were not fully verified, the formation of ammonia and its consumption through reaction with NO were evident. NO could adsorb on Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 as nitrate or nitrite, but the formation or storage of ammonia on it was not observed. The reaction paths of the H2-SCR of NO on Pt(1.0)/SiO2, Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2, and Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 were considerably different because the activated state of NO varied significantly with the nature of the supports. 3.3 Deactivation of the platinum catalysts The catalysts were tested before and after hydrothermal treatment and exposure to sulfur dioxide (Table 2 ). Hydrothermal treatment lowered NO conversion and N2 yield over Pt(1.0)/SiO2 but not Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 or Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2. Sulfur dioxide reduced NO conversion and N2 yield over Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 but did not affect Pt(1.0)/SiO2 or Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2. Hydrothermal treatment increased the diffraction peaks attributed to platinum metal on Pt(1.0)/SiO2, reflecting the metal's sintering and decrease of external surface area. The relatively strong interactions of platinum with alumina or zirconia suppressed the its sintering and maintained the catalytic activities of Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 and Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2, even after long treatment with water vapor at high temperatures. The accumulation of sulfate species on the external surfaces of Pt(1.0)/Al2O3 upon exposure to wet sulfur dioxide caused its deactivation. Despite Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2 forming zirconium sulfate upon exposure to wet sulfur dioxide, there was negligible masking of its external surface to suppress its activity. 4 Conclusions Platinum catalysts supported on zirconia-incorporated silica exhibited considerably improved performance in the H2-SCR of NO in the presence of excess oxygen compared with those supported on silica or alumina. The incorporation of zirconia onto silica generated strong acid sites that acted as adsorption sites for ammonia and stabilized the dispersed platinum through strong interactions between the platinum and zirconia. The incorporated zirconia aided the adsorption of NO, enhancing the formation of ammonia on Pt(1.0)/Zr–SiO2, even in excess oxygen. The formation of ammonia from the reaction of NO with hydrogen and the catalytic reduction of NO by the formed ammonia resulted in high NO conversions and high yields of N2. The incorporation of zirconia also improved the stability of platinum against hydrothermal treatment. Acknowledgments This work is part of the project ‘Development of Partial Zero Emission Technology for Future Vehicles’ funded by the Ministry of Knowledge Economy and the authors are grateful for its financial support. coredata.dc:description: The incorporation of zirconia onto the silica supports of platinum catalysts improved the selective reduction of NO by hydrogen in comparison to platinum catalysts supported on silica and alumina. The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and the adsorption of carbon monoxide. Their performances were examined in a flow microreactor and by in situ IR spectroscopy. The incorporation of zirconia onto silica created many strong acid sites and stabilized the dispersed platinum. It aided the adsorption of NO and enhanced the formation of ammonia on the platinum catalysts, even in the presence of excess oxygen. The formation of ammonia from NO and the subsequent removal of NO through reaction with ammonia considerably improved the conversion of NO and the yield of N2. The presence of zirconia also improved the stability of the supported platinum against hydrothermal treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Incorporation of zirconia onto silica for improved Pt/SiO2 catalysts for the selective reduction of NO by H2
